awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: PaiRED: Partnering Across Insider-views of RED
awd_abstract_narration:
Engineering programs across the country are working to become more responsive to the changing needs of today's students. In response to this need, the NSF has funded 19 five-year Revolutionizing Engineering and Computer Science Departments (RED) projects from 2015-17, with a call for new proposals published in 2018. The preliminary results from funded RED projects show many examples of success. Transformative organizational change is difficult, however, and most project teams have navigated challenges related to leadership team dynamics. Most of these challenges are not shared with the broader community, in part, because of a fear of identifying individuals and of highlighting failures instead of successes. Yet, understanding the challenges associated with relationships in leadership teams is critical to making revolutionary change in engineering education. This project will develop a deeper understanding of team dynamics in large-scale engineering teams. This new knowledge will ultimately increase the effectiveness of RED teams and their organizational change initiatives, and will have implications for other large-scale initiatives such as Engineering Research Centers.

This exploratory research project is focused on developing a critical understanding of roles, perspectives, and relationships within RED teams and the potential impact of these concepts on creating and sustaining organizational change to improve the education of engineers nationwide. The NSF PFE/IUSE: RED solicitation requires the inclusion of faculty and administrators who serve in specific roles and from specific backgrounds; this project develops an understanding of the lived experiences of the individuals who served in these roles on teams funded from 2015-2017. In particular, the work will investigate how the experiences of team members shape attempts at organizational change. The project explores the following research questions: How do roles, perspectives, relationships, and structures shape how teams face, frame, and navigate challenges and tensions, as they work towards revolutionary organizational change in engineering education? How have RED team roles, perspectives, relationships, and structures evolved over time? 

Data collection and analysis include artifact analysis of proposal documents, project websites, and shared RED documents. Narrative interviews with members of RED leadership teams, including principal investigators, social scientists, engineering education researchers, and disciplinary engineering faculty members will also be conducted. These data will be analyzed to identify larger patterns across interviews and develop broader themes. Findings will be disseminated in traditional venues, in workshops, and through white papers. By looking at the experiences of RED team members within specific roles across RED sites, key aspects of RED team dynamics (that cannot be reported on easily in individual teams because of the identifiable nature these roles) will be uncovered.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Initiated in 2014, NSF Revolutionizing Engineering Departments (RED) projects have funded interdisciplinary change teams to revolutionize engineering departments. The goal of the PaiRED (Partnering Across Insider-views of RED) project was to identify barriers and opportunities these change teams faced, considering the varied institution types and approaches. As many of these projects included a focus on justice, equity, diversity and inclusivity (JEDI), we were interested in understanding how aspects of gender, race, disciplinary affiliation, and university position were experienced and enacted on these teams; in other words, how power and privilege play out in team dynamics on these change teams. 

In order to develop understanding of how relationships, power, and privilege drive or stall the desired revolutionary changes, we interviewed 15 members of RED change teams representing a range of institution types and team roles. Interviewees shared forthright and detailed examples, sometimes depicting sexist or racist experiences vividly. These profound stories were moving, but we could not share them without identifying individuals involved. 

To deal with this, we developed a means of compositing multiple interviewee?s stories into one narrative while preserving confidentiality. These composited narratives included one that was based on a full professor who is a woman, another that was the PI of a project and a white man, and the last as an assistant professor who was a woman. To construct the narratives we engaged closely with the interview transcripts through multiple readings and listening to audio recordings and noted similarities and divergences across experiences. We structured the stories with a beginning, middle, and end. These composite narratives will be published in journal articles and will also be used in future workshops and communities of practice as a starting point for storycrafting and envisioning futures where JEDI change efforts thrive.

In analyzing these composited narratives, we realized that using only one framework or theory provided an incomplete picture of the work of making revolutionary change in engineering departments. In response, we developed a framework: the TRIPLE (Theories and Research on Intersectional Power, Learning, and Evolutionary) Change framework integrates theories of learning, change, and power in order to guide JEDI-oriented organizational change by attending to situated understandings of learning and an intersectional approach to power.  This framework can be used by others interested in studying change efforts, helping them analyze the impacts of learning and power in the process of change. The TRIPLE Change framework can also serve as a model for bringing theories into play with one another. This stands to address a well-known issue in which frameworks of power are used in isolation, providing characterizations of systemic oppression, yet offering little insight into how to change these situations.

We developed and presented workshops and shared educational resources in multiple venues including ASEE, FIE, CoNECD, and at the Regional discussion on sexual assault and sexual harassment at America's colleges, universities and service academies to identify ways power and privilege play out in intersectional ways in higher education. Specifically, we developed the POWER protocol (Privilege and Oppression: Working for Equitable Recourse), a workshop that guides engineering educators to identify and understand the intersectional nature of power and privilege before planning strategies to disrupt, disarm, and dismantle it. Our workshops slowly evolved over the course of the project as we intentionally brought in members of our advisory board and students to assist with the development of the workshops. Our last workshop at FIE earned the Helen Plants Outstanding Conference Special Session Award, which recognizes the best special session of the annual FIE conference.

Our work through this EAGER project promises to contribute to more successful institutional change projects. We did this through developing a method of compositing narratives, the development of the TRIPLE Change framework, and the design and presentation of workshops.

As another lasting impact of the PaiRED project, the team had opportunities to learn theory and research methods new to them, and this served to launch a new line of research that focuses on understanding how dynamics impact change teams.


Last Modified: 05/24/2022
Modified by: Vanessa Svihla

Image

    Vanessa Svihla, Nadia Kellam, & Susannah C Davis
    Creative Commons

    the TRIPLE (Theories and Research on Intersectional Power, Learning, and Evolutionary) Change framework
